thread.content:
There's a well-known expression in venture capital:

"Only a handful of companies per year actually matter" 

I thought it would be interesting to go back and find the Series A deals that actually "mattered" each year with the benefit of hindsight: üëá

semantic_predicates.name: other
semantic_predicates.label: other
semantic_predicates.prompt: This is a special tag. Use this tag if none of the tags above are suitable. If you tag a post with <other>, no other tag should be assigned to the post.
semantic_predicates.prompt_zero_ref: This is a special tag. Use this tag if none of the tags above are suitable. If you tag a post with <other>, no other tag should be assigned to the post.

semantic_predicates.name: disagreesWith
semantic_predicates.label: disagrees
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post disputes or expresses disagreement with statements, ideas or conclusions presented in the mentioned reference.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post disputes or expresses disagreement with statements, ideas or conclusions presented in the mentioned reference.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: this reference is being disputed by the post. The post expresses disagreement with statements, ideas or conclusions presented in the mentioned reference.

semantic_predicates.name: possibleMissingReference
semantic_predicates.label: missing-ref
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post seems to be referring to a reference by name but has not explicitly provided a URL link to the reference. For example, a post that discusses a book and mentions it by title, but contains no link to the book.
semantic_predicates.prompt_zero_ref: this post seems to be referring to a reference by name but has not explicitly provided a URL link to the reference. For example, a post that discusses a book and mentions it by title, but contains no link to the book.

semantic_predicates.name: reviews
semantic_predicates.label: review
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post contains a review of another reference, such as a book, article or movie. The review could be positive or negative. A review can be detailed or a simple short endorsement.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post contains a review of another reference, such as a book, article or movie. The review could be positive or negative. A review can be detailed or a simple short endorsement.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: the reference is being reviewed by the post. The reference could be a book, article or movie, or other media content. The review could be positive or negative.

semantic_predicates.name: question
semantic_predicates.label: dg-question
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post is raising a research question.
semantic_predicates.prompt_zero_ref: this post is raising a research question.

semantic_predicates.name: announcesResource
semantic_predicates.label: announce
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post contains an announcement of new research. The announcement is likely made by the authors but may be a third party. We use a broad definition of research that includes classic and non-traditional outputs. Classic outputs include papers, datasets or code. Non traditional outputs can include a podcast, blog post, video explainers, etc.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post contains an announcement of new research. The announcement is likely made by the authors but may be a third party. We use a broad definition of research that includes classic and non-traditional outputs. Classic outputs include papers, datasets or code. Non traditional outputs can include a podcast, blog post, video explainers, etc.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: the reference is a new research output being announced by the post. The announcement is likely made by the authors but may be a third party. A research output could be a paper, dataset or other type of research that is being announced publicly.

semantic_predicates.name: endorses
semantic_predicates.label: endorses
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post endorses the mentioned reference. This label can also be used for cases of implicit recommendation, where the author is expressing enjoyment of some content but not explicitly recommending it.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post endorses the mentioned reference. This label can also be used for cases of implicit recommendation, where the author is expressing enjoyment of some content but not explicitly recommending it.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: the post endorses this reference. This label can also be used for cases of implicit recommendation, where the author is expressing enjoyment of some content but not explicitly recommending it.

semantic_predicates.name: discusses
semantic_predicates.label: discussion
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post discusses how the cited reference relates to other facts or claims. For example, post might discuss how the cited reference informs questions, provides evidence, or supports or opposes claims.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post discusses how the cited reference relates to other facts or claims. For example, post might discuss how the cited reference informs questions, provides evidence, or supports or opposes claims.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: this post discusses how the cited reference relates to other facts or claims. For example, post might discuss how the cited reference informs questions, provides evidence, or supports or opposes claims.

semantic_predicates.name: mentionsListeningStatus
semantic_predicates.label: listening
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post describes the listening status of the author in relation to a reference, such as a podcast or radio station. The author may have listened to the content in the past, is listening to the content in the present, or is looking forward to listening the content in the future.
semantic_predicates.prompt_zero_ref: this post describes the listening status of the author in relation to a reference, such as a podcast or radio station. The author may have listened to the content in the past, is listening to the content in the present, or is looking forward to listening the content in the future.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post describes the listening status of the author in relation to a reference, such as a podcast or radio station. The author may have listened to the content in the past, is listening to the content in the present, or is looking forward to listening the content in the future.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: this post describes the listening status of the author in relation to this reference, such as a podcast or radio station. The author may have listened to the content in the past, is listening to the content in the present, or is looking forward to listening the content in the future.

semantic_predicates.name: recommends
semantic_predicates.label: recommendation
semantic_predicates.prompt: The author is recommending any kind of content: an article, a movie, podcast, book, another post, etc.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: The author is recommending any kind of content: an article, a movie, podcast, book, another post, etc.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: The author is recommending the reference, which can be any kind of content: an article, a movie, podcast, book, another post, etc. This tag can also be used for cases of implicit recommendation, where the author is expressing enjoyment of some content but not explicitly recommending it.

semantic_predicates.name: mentionsCallForPapers
semantic_predicates.label: call-for-papers
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post contains a call for research papers, for example to a journal, conference or workshop.
semantic_predicates.prompt_zero_ref: this post contains a call for research papers, for example to a journal, conference or workshop.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post contains a call for research papers, for example to a journal, conference or workshop.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: this reference contains a call for research papers, for example to a journal, conference or workshop.

semantic_predicates.name: includesQuotationFrom
semantic_predicates.label: quote
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post is quoting text from an article it's referring to. Symbols like ">" or quotation marks are often used to indicate quotations.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post is quoting text from an article it's referring to. Symbols like ">" or quotation marks are often used to indicate quotations.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: this reference is being quoted in the post. Symbols like ">" or quotation marks are often used to indicate quotations.

semantic_predicates.name: asksQuestionAbout
semantic_predicates.label: question
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post is raising a question or questions about some content it's referring to. The content could be a research paper or other media like a podcast, video or blog post.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post is raising a question or questions about some content it's referring to. The content could be a research paper or other media like a podcast, video or blog post.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: this post is raising a question or questions about the reference. The content could be a research paper or other media like a podcast, video or blog post.

semantic_predicates.name: agreesWith
semantic_predicates.label: agrees
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post expresses agreement with statements, ideas or conclusions presented in the mentioned reference.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post expresses agreement with statements, ideas or conclusions presented in the mentioned reference.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: this post expresses agreement with statements, ideas or conclusions presented in this reference.

semantic_predicates.name: observation
semantic_predicates.label: dg-observation
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post is articulating a single, highly observation. The intuition is that observation notes should be as close to ‚Äúthe data‚Äù as possible. They should be similar to how results are described in results sections of academic publications.
semantic_predicates.prompt_zero_ref: this post is articulating a single, highly observation. The intuition is that observation notes should be as close to ‚Äúthe data‚Äù as possible. They should be similar to how results are described in results sections of academic publications.

semantic_predicates.name: claim
semantic_predicates.label: dg-claim
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post is articulating an idea or a claim
semantic_predicates.prompt_zero_ref: this post is articulating an idea or a claim

semantic_predicates.name: mentionsFundingOpportunity
semantic_predicates.label: funding
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post mentions a funding opportunity, for example a research grant or prize.
semantic_predicates.prompt_zero_ref: this post mentions a funding opportunity, for example a research grant or prize.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post mentions a funding opportunity, for example a research grant or prize.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: this reference contains a funding opportunity, for example a research grant or prize.

semantic_predicates.name: summarizes
semantic_predicates.label: summarizes
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post contains a summary of the mentioned reference. The summary is likely provided by the authors but may be a third party.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post contains a summary of the mentioned reference. The summary is likely provided by the authors but may be a third party.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: this reference is summarized by the post. The summary is likely provided by the authors but may be a third party.

semantic_predicates.name: mentionsWatchingStatus
semantic_predicates.label: watching
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post describes the watching status of the author in relation to a reference, such as a video or movie. The author may have watched the content in the past, is watching the content in the present, or is looking forward to watching the content in the future.
semantic_predicates.prompt_zero_ref: this post describes the watching status of the author in relation to a reference, such as a video or movie. The author may have watched the content in the past, is watching the content in the present, or is looking forward to watching the content in the future.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post describes the watching status of the author in relation to a reference, such as a video or movie. The author may have watched the content in the past, is watching the content in the present, or is looking forward to watching the content in the future.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: this post describes the watching status of the author in relation to this reference, such as a video or movie. The author may have watched the content in the past, is watching the content in the present, or is looking forward to watching the content in the future.

semantic_predicates.name: mentionsReadingStatus
semantic_predicates.label: reading
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post describes the reading status of the author in relation to a reference, such as a book or article. The author may either have read the reference in the past, is reading the reference in the present, or is looking forward to reading the reference in the future.
semantic_predicates.prompt_zero_ref: this post describes the reading status of the author in relation to a reference, such as a book or article. The author may either have read the reference in the past, is reading the reference in the present, or is looking forward to reading the reference in the future.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post describes the reading status of the author in relation to a reference, such as a book or article. The author may either have read the reference in the past, is reading the reference in the present, or is looking forward to reading the reference in the future.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: this post describes the reading status of the author in relation to this reference, which could be a book, article or other written media. The author may either have read the reference in the past, is reading the reference in the present, or is looking forward to reading the reference in the future.

semantic_predicates.name: announcesEvent
semantic_predicates.label: event
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post includes an invitation to an event, either a real-world or an online event. Any kind of event is relevant, some examples of such events could be seminars, meetups, or hackathons. This tag should only be used for invitations to events, not for posts describing other kinds of events.
semantic_predicates.prompt_zero_ref: this post includes an invitation to an event, either a real-world or an online event. Any kind of event is relevant, some examples of such events could be seminars, meetups, or hackathons. This tag should only be used for invitations to events, not for posts describing other kinds of events.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post includes an invitation to an event, either a real-world or an online event. Any kind of event is relevant, some examples of such events could be seminars, meetups, or hackathons. This tag should only be used for invitations to events, not for posts describing other kinds of events.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: the reference is an invitation to an event, either a real-world or an online event. Any kind of event is relevant, some examples of such events could be seminars, meetups, or hackathons. This tag shold only be used for invitations to events, not for posts describing other kinds of events.

semantic_predicates.name: announcesJob
semantic_predicates.label: job
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post describes a job listing, for example a call for graduate students or faculty applications.
semantic_predicates.prompt_zero_ref: this post describes a job listing, for example a call for graduate students or faculty applications.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post describes a job listing, for example a call for graduate students or faculty applications.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: the reference is a job listing, for example a call for graduate students or faculty applications.

semantic_predicates.name: indicatesInterest
semantic_predicates.label: indicates-interest
semantic_predicates.prompt: this post indicates interest in a reference. This label is meant for cases where the post is not explicitly recommending or endorsing the cited reference.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: this post indicates interest in a reference. This label is meant for cases where the post is not explicitly recommending or endorsing the cited reference.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: the post is indicating interest in this reference. This label is meant for cases where the post is not explicitly recommending or endorsing this reference.

semantic_predicates.name: linksTo
semantic_predicates.label: default
semantic_predicates.prompt: This is a special tag. Use this tag if none of the tags above are suitable. If you tag a post with <default>, no other tag should be assigned to the post.
semantic_predicates.prompt_single_ref: This is a special tag. Use this tag if none of the tags above are suitable. If you tag a post with <default>, no other tag should be assigned to the post.
semantic_predicates.prompt_multi_ref: This is a special tag. Use this tag if none of the other tags are suitable to characterize this reference.

multi_reference_tagger.prompt:
You are an expert annotator tasked with converting social media posts about scientific research to a structured semantic format. The post contains external references in the form of links (URLs). Your job is to select, for each reference, the tags best characterizing the relation of the post to the reference.

# Instructions
## Tag types
The tags are to be selected from a predefined set of tags. The available tag types are:
<disagrees>: this reference is being disputed by the post. The post expresses disagreement with statements, ideas or conclusions presented in the mentioned reference.
<review>: the reference is being reviewed by the post. The reference could be a book, article or movie, or other media content. The review could be positive or negative.
<announce>: the reference is a new research output being announced by the post. The announcement is likely made by the authors but may be a third party. A research output could be a paper, dataset or other type of research that is being announced publicly.
<endorses>: the post endorses this reference. This label can also be used for cases of implicit recommendation, where the author is expressing enjoyment of some content but not explicitly recommending it.
<discussion>: this post discusses how the cited reference relates to other facts or claims. For example, post might discuss how the cited reference informs questions, provides evidence, or supports or opposes claims.
<listening>: this post describes the listening status of the author in relation to this reference, such as a podcast or radio station. The author may have listened to the content in the past, is listening to the content in the present, or is looking forward to listening the content in the future.
<recommendation>: The author is recommending the reference, which can be any kind of content: an article, a movie, podcast, book, another post, etc. This tag can also be used for cases of implicit recommendation, where the author is expressing enjoyment of some content but not explicitly recommending it.
<call-for-papers>: this reference contains a call for research papers, for example to a journal, conference or workshop.
<quote>: this reference is being quoted in the post. Symbols like ">" or quotation marks are often used to indicate quotations. 
<question>: this post is raising a question or questions about the reference. The content could be a research paper or other media like a podcast, video or blog post.
<agrees>: this post expresses agreement with statements, ideas or conclusions presented in this reference.
<funding>: this reference contains a funding opportunity, for example a research grant or prize.
<summarizes>: this reference is summarized by the post. The summary is likely provided by the authors but may be a third party.
<watching>: this post describes the watching status of the author in relation to this reference, such as a video or movie. The author may have watched the content in the past, is watching the content in the present, or is looking forward to watching the content in the future.
<reading>: this post describes the reading status of the author in relation to this reference, which could be a book, article or other written media. The author may either have read the reference in the past, is reading the reference in the present, or is looking forward to reading the reference in the future.
<event>: the reference is an invitation to an event, either a real-world or an online event. Any kind of event is relevant, some examples of such events could be seminars, meetups, or hackathons. This tag shold only be used for invitations to events, not for posts describing other kinds of events.
<job>: the reference is a job listing, for example a call for graduate students or faculty applications.
<indicates-interest>: the post is indicating interest in this reference. This label is meant for cases where the post is not explicitly recommending or endorsing this reference.
<default>: This is a special tag. Use this tag if none of the other tags are suitable to characterize this reference.

A user will pass in a post, and you should reason step by step, before selecting a set of tags for each reference that best that reference's relation with the post.

## Reference metadata
Each reference will be marked by <ref_n> for convenient identification, where n is a number denoting the order of appearance in the post. The first reference will be <ref_1>, the second <ref_2>, etc. Additional metadata may also be provided for references, such as the author name, content type, and summary.

### Quote posts
Quote posts are a special kind of reference, where the post quotes another post. In which case, the quoted post content will be enclosed by <quote ref_n> (quote content) </quote>. Note that quote content may itself contain references.


## Required output format
Your final answer should be structured as a JSON Answer object with a list of SubAnswer objects, as described by the following schemas:


```
class SubAnswer:
	ref_number: int # ID number of current reference
	reasoning_steps: str # your reasoning steps
	candidate_tags: str # For potential each tag you choose, explain why you chose it.
	final_answer: List[str] # a set of final tags, based on the Candidate Tags. The final tags must be included in the Candidate Tags list!

class Answer:
  sub_answers: List[SubAnswer]
```


For example, for a post with 2 references, the output would be structured as follows:

```
{
  "sub_answers": [
  {
    "ref_number": 1,
    "reasoning_steps": "<your reasoning steps...>",
    "candidate_tags": "[<tag1>, <tag2>]",
    "final_answer": [
      "<tag1>"
    ]
  },
  {
    "ref_number": 2,
    "reasoning_steps": "<your reasoning steps...>",
    "candidate_tags": "[<tag1>, <tag3>, <tag4>]",
    "final_answer": [
      "<tag3>",
      "<tag4>"
    ]
  }
]
}
```


# Input post text:

- Author: Brian Gordon
- Content: Noted <ref_1> <quoted ref_2>There's a well-known expression in venture capital:

"Only a handful of companies per year actually matter" 

I thought it would be interesting to go back and find the Series A deals that actually "mattered" each year with the benefit of hindsight: üëá</quote>
- References: 
<ref_1> 
url: https://x.com/colerotman/status/1863422595942773233
item_type: forumPost
title: Twitter post
summary: None
==========
<ref_2> 
url: https://x.com/ColeRotman/status/1863422595942773233
item_type: forumPost
title: Twitter post
summary: None
==========


# Output:

0.steps: The post is referencing a Twitter post (ref_1) and quoting another Twitter post (ref_2). The author, Brian Gordon, is discussing the content of the quoted post and does not seem to disagree or endorse it. Instead, he is interested in the topic and wants to explore it further.

1.steps: The post is quoting a Twitter post (ref_2), which contains a well-known expression in venture capital. The author, Brian Gordon, is using this quote as a starting point for his own discussion. He does not seem to disagree or endorse the quote, but rather uses it to introduce his own thoughts on the topic.

topics.full_text:
Reasoning Steps:
1. Identify the type of content and its source. In this case, the content is a Twitter post.
2. Analyze the content of the Twitter post to understand the main topic being discussed.
3. Match the main topic to the available topic types.

Candidate Topics:
- technology: The Twitter post may discuss a new technology, product, or service.
- culture: The Twitter post may discuss cultural trends or issues.
- personal: The Twitter post may express personal opinions or experiences.
- humour: The Twitter post may be intended to be humorous.

Final Answer: Based on the analysis of the Twitter post, the most salient topic discussed is technology. The final topics are therefore:
- technology
- personal (as the post may express personal opinions)
- humour (if the post is intended to be humorous)

Note: Without the actual content of the Twitter post, it is not possible to determine if the post is related to culture or not. However, the final topics include culture as a potential topic. 

 ##Allowed terms: ['technology', 'science', 'academia', 'research', 'design', 'climate', 'sustainability', 'software & hardware', 'philosophy', 'health', 'culture', 'economics', 'business', 'politics', 'news', 'finance', 'sports', 'entertainment & leisure', 'art', 'literature', 'travel', 'personal', 'humour', 'other']
topics.prompt:
You are an expert annotator tasked with assigning topics to social media posts. The assigned topics should represent the most salient topics discussed by the post.  

The available topic types are:
- technology
- science
- academia
- research
- design
- climate
- sustainability
- software & hardware
- philosophy
- health
- culture
- economics
- business
- politics
- news
- finance
- sports
- entertainment & leisure
- art
- literature
- travel
- personal
- humour
- other

A user will pass in a post, and you should think step by step, before selecting a set of topics that best match the post. You must only use the topics in the list!


Rules:
- Your final answer should be structured as follows:
    - Reasoning Steps: (your reasoning steps)
    - Candidate Topics: (For potential each topic you choose, explain why you chose it.)
    - Final Answer: (a set of final topics, based on the Candidate Topics. The rest of the final keywords must be included in the Candidate Topics list!)

2. Analyze the content of the Twitter post to understand the main topic being discussed.
3. Match the main topic to the available topic types.

[Candidate Tags]

keywords.raw_text:
Reasoning Steps:

1. Analyze the content and references of the post.
2. Identify the general and specific topics discussed in the post and its references.
3. Determine if the post is related to academic research.

Candidate Keywords:

1. #Twitter: The post contains Twitter links, indicating that the post is related to Twitter.
2. #Monte-Carlo-Tree-Search: The references mention Monte-Carlo-Tree-Search, indicating that the post is discussing this topic.
3. #Reinforcement-Learning: The references mention reinforcement learning, indicating that the post is discussing this topic.
4. #AI: Monte-Carlo-Tree-Search and reinforcement learning are subfields of artificial intelligence, indicating that the post is discussing AI.
5. #Research: The references are to a research paper and a forum discussing research, indicating that the post is related to research.
6. #Academic: The references are to a research paper and a forum discussing research, indicating that the post is related to academic research.

Final Answer:

1. #Twitter
2. #Monte-Carlo-Tree-Search
3. #Reinforcement-Learning
4. #AI
5. #Research
6. #Academic
keywords.prompt:
You are an expert annotator tasked with assigning keywords to social media posts. The keywords should represent the most salient topics discussed by the post. The keywords should consist of two types: general and specific. The general keywords should indicate the general topics discussed by the posts and its references, like "#AI" or "#blockchain". The specific keywords should highlight specific that will help people in the field better understand the post's contents (like "#monte-carlo-tree-search", or "#consensus-algorithms"). In addition to the above, you should also add a special '#academic' keyword if the post is related to academic research. Acaedmic research is to be defined broadly, as anything that the author is likely to see as related to their research, including academic job offers, code repositories, blog posts and so on. If the post is clearly not related in any way to academic research, add '#not-academic'. 

Rules:
- You should choose up to 6 keywords, plus the additional special academic/non-academic keyword!
- Keywords should be prefixed with a hashtag, e.g., #AI
- Your final answer should be structured as follows:
    - Reasoning Steps: (your reasoning steps)
    - Candidate Keywords: (For potential each keyword you choose, explain why you chose it.)
    - Final Answer: (a set of 7 final keywords, based on the Candidate Keywords. One of the keywords should be #academic or #not-academic. The rest of the final keywords must be included in the Candidate Keywords list!)

There's a well-known expression in venture capital:

"Only a handful of companies per year actually matter" 

I thought it would be interesting to go back and find the Series A deals that actually "mattered" each year with the benefit of hindsight: üëá

note_tweet.text:
There's a well-known expression in venture capital:

"Only a handful of companies per year actually matter" 

I thought it would be interesting to go back and find the Series A deals that actually "mattered" each year with the benefit of hindsight: üëá
